2.rationale:
Let's re-evaluate our situation. Our snake (ID #2) is at (2,7) and we have apples at (9,5), (6,6), (7,1), (3,4), and (1,0). Calculating Manhattan distances from our current position:

• Apple (3,4): |3–2| + |4–7| = 1 + 3 = 4  
• Apple (6,6): |6–2| + |6–7| = 4 + 1 = 5  
• Apple (1,0): |1–2| + |0–7| = 1 + 7 = 8  
• Apple (9,5): |9–2| + |5–7| = 7 + 2 = 9  
• Apple (7,1): |7–2| + |1–7| = 5 + 6 = 11  

The closest by Manhattan distance is the apple at (3,4).

Now, from (2,7) we want to approach (3,4). We have two moves that decrease the Manhattan distance to 3:
• Moving RIGHT to (3,7) gives a new distance of |3–3| + |7–4| = 0 + 3 = 3.  
• Moving DOWN to (2,6) gives a new distance of |3–2| + |6–4| = 1 + 2 = 3.

Both moves are safe since none go off the board or hit our enemy (the enemy snake at (6,7) is well clear).

Choosing between the two, moving DOWN has the benefit of immediately reducing our y-coordinate, which is crucial since our target (3,4) is lower (y = 4). This positions us to subsequently use a RIGHT move to align perfectly with x = 3, all while steadily descending towards the apple.

Thus, the strategy is: from (2,7), move DOWN to (2,6), then likely follow with RIGHT moves as needed to reach (3,4).

Next move: DOWN.
